author: Jack Davis
title: Service Member Says Farewell To A Partner And Friend
text:
Service Member Says Farewell To A Partner And Friend “I’ve never cried that much ..." by Jack Davis March 7, 2017 at 12:11pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
A veteran who served his country and was loyal until the end received a final, tearful farewell recently as Kyle Smith, held the flag-draped body of Bodza , a retired military service dog. Retired @usairforce MWD Bodza (L068) passed away with his dad Kyle by his side on February 21st. Rest easy and run free. pic.twitter.com/E61sVNpekT 
Bodza, who spent eight years as a bomb-sniffing dog for the Air Force, was first paired with Smith during a tour of duty in Kyrgyzstan. Smith later adopted the dog when Bodza was retired from the military in 2014. Advertisement - story continues below Hannity: Americans Can’t Afford The Cost And Crime Of Illegal Immigration 
The dog’s ailing health had brought Smith to take him to the Fort Bliss Vet Clinic in El Paso, Texas, last week. 
“It was the saddest thing — he was dragging himself along the tile floor because it was hard to maneuver,” Smith said. With fellow service members helping him, Smith placed Bodza on blankets on the floor. 
“I just kept holding him, rubbing and kissing his head, telling him, ‘I’m going to miss you.'” Advertisement - story continues below 
The time came for the drugs to allow Bodza to drift off forever. 
“I held him in my arms the entire time,” said Smith. “I’ve never cried that much my entire life.” 
“There was heartache and peace all at once that came over me,” Smith said later. “I will never forget how loyal he was … He was selfless — more than any human I’ve ever known. He’s done so much for next to nothing and did it with a smile. I miss him every day.” 
When Smith’s superiors learned about Bodza, they wanted to show their respect. Advertisement - story continues below 
“My boss immediately said, ‘Where’s your American flag? You should have one in your building. Find it for me now.'” Smith said. 
They draped the flag over Bodza’s body, in recognition for his service to the country. 
“The worst thing you can do is not to recognize these dogs for what they are,” Smith explained. “For these guys to do this for a dog they’ve never even met.” 
Smith recalled the day he adopted Bodza in 2014. 
“My boss said, ‘Hey, go check your Jeep,'” Smith said. “They went out and put a bowl, a brand new leash and two collars, and they put (Bodza) at the back of my Jeep. I got to take him home the same day he retired.” 
“My favorite thing about him was he didn’t care what you were doing, he just wanted to be there doing it with you,” he said. “Pretty much my whole career with him was walking around something, or walking to somewhere.” 
“He was even more loyal at home,” Smith said. “He followed me around everywhere. He would lay his head down flush with the bed and tell me goodnight, every night.” 
“All of us have that dog that is so special to us,” Smith said. “I got married with this dog, I got divorced with this dog. I have a son on the way, and the most heartbreaking part is I really wish he was younger, so my son would be able to play with him. He was the nicest dog in the world.” What do you think?
